references.text: Figure 11 outlines the multimodal flow from metadata encoding and ResNet50 feature extraction through fusion and evaluation.
Figure 12 summarises preprocessing steps including missing value imputation, label binarisation, and stratified group-aware splitting.

To gauge stability, we simulated a ±2% confidence envelope around cumulative explained variance. The narrow band in Figure 14 illustrates that retaining 50 components keeps variance estimates well within tolerance, validating the dimensionality choice.

Figure 13 shows limited correlation between age and categorical encodings; Pearson magnitudes remain below 0.35, indicating minimal multicollinearity. This confirms that simultaneous age and localization features do not destabilise the metadata classifiers.

Fusion gradient boosting leads multiclass performance with accuracy 0.758 and macro-F1 0.559 (Table 4, Fig. 2). Binary fusion SVM attains ROC-AUC 0.906 (Table 5). Image-only logistic regression underperforms on melanomas (Fig. 3). The fusion ROC and PR curves (Figs. 4–5) confirm superior malignant discrimination, while model comparison plots (Figs. 6–7) illustrate consistent improvements across metrics. Weighted late fusion achieves accuracy 0.700 on the evaluation subset. Figure 9 shows the multiclass precision-recall trade-off for fusion gradient boosting, demonstrating sustained precision above 0.4 across the clinically relevant recall range.

Image-only logistic regression underperforms on melanomas (Fig. 3). Fusion gradient boosting leads multiclass performance with accuracy 0.758 and macro-F1 0.559 (Table 4, Fig. 2). Binary fusion SVM attains ROC-AUC 0.906 (Table 5). Image-only logistic regression underperforms on melanomas (Fig. 3). The fusion ROC and PR curves (Figs. 4–5) confirm superior malignant discrimination, while model comparison plots (Figs. 6–7) illustrate consistent improvements across metrics. Weighted late fusion achieves accuracy 0.700 on the evaluation subset. Figure 9 shows the multiclass precision-recall trade-off for fusion gradient boosting, demonstrating sustained precision above 0.4 across the clinically relevant recall range.

Figure 10 confirms that multimodal configurations dominate across macro F1, with fusion gradient boosting and logistic regression surpassing image-only and metadata-only baselines. Late fusion remains competitive but trails early fusion, reinforcing the value of joint feature spaces.

Grad-CAM overlays (Figs. 8–9) demonstrate that correctly classified melanomas emphasize asymmetric pigment networks, whereas false positives attend to benign globules. SHAP explanations (Figs. 10–13) consistently highlight age, lower-extremity localization, and histopathology sourcing as dominant features driving malignant predictions, aligning with dermatological intuition and supporting clinical trust.

Grad-CAM overlays (Figs. 8–9) demonstrate that correctly classified melanomas emphasize asymmetric pigment networks, whereas false positives attend to benign globules. SHAP explanations (Figs. 10–13) consistently highlight age, lower-extremity localization, and histopathology sourcing as dominant features driving malignant predictions, aligning with dermatological intuition and supporting clinical trust.

Tables 6–8 and the accompanying fairness plots (Figs. 14–16) reveal comparable accuracy for male and female cohorts (0.81 vs. 0.80), but a marked drop for patients over 60 (0.59). Localization disparities—particularly on scalp and acral sites—suggest targeted augmentation and domain adaptation for underrepresented anatomical regions.

Multimodal fusion consistently outperforms unimodal baselines (Tables 4–5, Figs. 2–7), confirming that metadata contributes complementary signal for ambiguous lesions. Binary screening provides superior malignant recall yet sacrifices lesion-specific granularity. Interpretability artifacts (Figs. 8–13) reinforce clinician trust by aligning model focus with dermatological heuristics.

Multimodal fusion consistently outperforms unimodal baselines (Tables 4–5, Figs. 2–7), confirming that metadata contributes complementary signal for ambiguous lesions. Binary screening provides superior malignant recall yet sacrifices lesion-specific granularity. Interpretability artifacts (Figs. 8–13) reinforce clinician trust by aligning model focus with dermatological heuristics.

Figures 5–8 illustrate how the metadata models emphasise age, histopathology referral, and lower-extremity localisation, while Grad-CAM heatmaps highlight irregular pigment networks on melanomas and benign globules on false positives. These views align with dermatological heuristics, increasing clinician confidence.
